subject: Re: Can anyone help me see how to usefully work with JUnit in a big project, please?

messageBody:
Cedric,
I think this is more of what Joakim meant. I had attended a
presentation by Robert "Uncle Bob" Martin on Test Driven
development. I think the exact example was a program to keep track
of a bowling game score. Presenting the Big view object model and
one done through incremental, test driven development, the later was
much simpler. It only required the creation of objects needed to
solve the problem rather then the apparent objects and their
behaviour.

David

wrote:

> On 10/27/06, Joakim Ohlrogge <joakim.ohlrogge@...> wrote:
> >
> >
> > I think, when doing TDD the main benefit is not to find bugs it
is to
> > guide
> > your design.
>
>
> Really?
>
> The main reason why I write tests is to make sure that no
regressions will
> happen. From the point where I submit my tests, I know that no
matter what
> code gets checked in after me, the functionality of the system
will not
> decrease.
>
> Tests also help a great deal make my code more robust.
>
> But drive my design with tests? That's dangerous and can
potentially lead to
> micro-design, i.e. design without seeing the big picture ("I'll
use this
> signature because the test looks cleaner then").
>
> --
> Cédric
